lines.text: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: There's not a man I meet but doth salute me As if I were their well-acquainted friend; And every one doth call me by my name. Some tender money to me; some invite me; Some other give me thanks for kindnesses; Some offer me commodities to buy: Even now a tailor call'd me in his shop And show'd me silks that he had bought for me, And therewithal took measure of my body. Sure, these are but imaginary wiles And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here.
Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Master, here's the gold you sent me for. What, have you got the picture of old Adam new-apparelled? ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: What gold is this? what Adam dost thou mean?

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Not that Adam that kept the Paradise but that Adam that keeps the prison: he that goes in the calf's skin that was killed for the Prodigal; he that came behind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: I understand thee not.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: No? why, 'tis a plain case: he that went, like a bass-viol, in a case of leather; the man, sir, that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a sob and 'rests them; he, sir, that takes pity on decayed men and gives them suits of durance; he that sets up his rest to do more exploits with his mace than a morris-pike. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: What, thou meanest an officer?

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band, he that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; one that thinks a man always going to bed, and says, 'God give you good rest!' ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is there any

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Why, sir, I brought you word an hour since that the bark Expedition put forth to-night; and then were you hindered by the sergeant, to tarry for the hoy Delay. Here are the angels that you sent for to deliver you. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: The fellow is distract, and so am I; And here we wander in illusions: Some blessed power deliver us from hence!
Enter a Courtezan

lines.speaker: courtezan
lines.text: Well met, well met, Master Antipholus. I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now: Is that the chain you promised me to-day? ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Satan, avoid! I charge thee, tempt me not.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Master, is this Mistress Satan? ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: It is the devil.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Nay, she is worse, she is the devil's dam; and here she comes in the habit of a light wench: and thereof comes that the wenches say 'God damn me;' that's as much to say 'God make me a light wench.' It is written, they appear to men like angels of light: light is an effect of fire, and fire will burn; ergo, light wenches will burn. Come not near her.

lines.speaker: courtezan
lines.text: Your man and you are marvellous merry, sir. Will you go with me? We'll mend our dinner here?

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Master, if you do, expect spoon-meat; or bespeak a long spoon. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Why, Dromio?

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Marry, he must have a long spoon that must eat with the devil. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Avoid then, fiend! what tell'st thou me of supping? Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress: I conjure thee to leave me and be gone.

lines.speaker: courtezan
lines.text: Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner, Or, for my diamond, the chain you promised, And I'll be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Some devils ask but the parings of one's nail, A rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin, A nut, a cherry-stone; But she, more covetous, would have a chain. Master, be wise: an if you give it her, The devil will shake her chain and fright us with it.

lines.speaker: courtezan
lines.text: I pray you, sir, my ring, or else the chain: I hope you do not mean to cheat me so. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Avaunt, thou witch! Come, Dromio, let us go.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: 'Fly pride,' says the peacock: mistress, that you know.
Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse

lines.speaker: courtezan
lines.text: Now, out of doubt Antipholus is mad, Else would he never so demean himself. A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats, And for the same he promised me a chain: Both one and other he denies me now. The reason that I gather he is mad, Besides this present instance of his rage, Is a mad tale he told to-day at dinner, Of his own doors being shut against his entrance. Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits, On purpose shut the doors against his way. My way is now to hie home to his house, And tell his wife that, being lunatic, He rush'd into my house and took perforce My ring away. This course I fittest choose; For forty ducats is too much to lose. ANTIPHOLUS
Exit
